lexUnit.name: presumption.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an act or instance of presuming something to be the case.

sentence.text: Although Government could alter the proposals , the presumption was that they would not .
One of the few criticisms that has rankled with Mr Kinnock has been the allegation of cockiness -- the presumption he has won before the votes have been counted .
The presumption that insolvency was criminal was no longer allowed .
When dealing with requests such as this we treat each on its merits , but the presumption is that an existing position is retained unless a more satisfactory alternative location is identified .
( b ) Continuations There is a statutory presumption that where a partnership continues after the time fixed for its termination the provisions of the original agreement will continue to apply .
In both these cases , the presumption is of service seven calendar days after the date of posting or insertion .
A trader should never act on the presumption of retrieving his circumstances when he had become flagrantly insolvent .
That there is strong presumption against interpreting a statute as taking away the right of silence , at least in some of its forms , can not in my view be doubted .
Our presumption has been that the police adhere to them .
His presumption that , through her body , a woman signifies inferiority , rests on a mistaken biology .

There can be no general presumption in favour of either indirect or direct taxation , when we assess each system in terms of macro-management , economic incentives , economic welfare and administrative costs .

By themselves the facts are neutral but in so far as moral views about the proper role of the media are based upon presumptions about facts , our empirical findings are bound to have moral implications .
To avoid any presumptions about the structure of the DNA , we replaced the bent DNA in the actual complex with the phosphate backbone for B-form DNA that was used to model the CAP/DNA complex .
The problem is dealt with mainly by presumptions about normal people .

Each model can cope with all the evidence and the choice between them is thrown back on criteria like elegance , economy , fruitfulness , or perhaps , indeed , conformity with deep underlying presumptions about human nature .
I think you should wait for that and do n't make any presumptions about the future of the runway .
Making yourself aware of bias and adopting alternative usages should prevent the tacit presumption by your reader of the white male as a norm .
And it warns : ` A presumption of the right to make an extra-contractual referral can not be a guarantee that the DHA would in all cases agree to meet the cost . "
The presumption of innocence has not been toppled ; rather , it has been corroded by a series of laws on alcohol and tobacco , football hooliganism , drugs , videos and even badgers .
In medieval times , the normal presumption of the courts was that any history or implication of consent on the part of the woman was a valid defence to an appeal of rape .
There was a significant challenge to the establishment inherent in Methodism 's message , its organisational novelties and its presumption of spiritual equality .
The presumption behind such arguments is that theists wish their statements about God to be propositions that it would be impossible to deny .
Above all , the extremely strong presumption against the legality of the use of nuclear weapons needs not only to be reaffirmed , but also made more specific .
An important presumption to which we should all adhere is that existing frontiers , however inconvenient and however arbitrarily they may have been drawn , are the lines from which we start .
The ` rationale for some of the more rigid land constraints which flow from national policies " also needs review , particularly the planning presumption against development of agricultural land .
` There should always be a presumption in favour of development unless there are specific reasons .
In these circumstances the presumption that the agent is a competent judge of what is best to do is very hard to maintain .
But there is already much evidence to support the presumption that the effect was pervasive .
As noted above , there is some indication of the development of a rebuttable presumption that all questions of law should be for the ordinary courts .
With a conscious effort , she swallowed the small spurt of irritation against his easy presumption that she 'd simply fall into line with whatever he chose to do .
3.3 It has been a recurrent presumption that the attributive position is in some sense or other a disguised form of the predicative position .
Many houses consisted of one storey only but in a number of instances , as at Priene , stairs have been excavated , leading to the presumption that an upper story had been constructed .
